abstract.p: Stephen Holden reviews performance by singer-pianist Steve Ross, at Firebird Cafe; photo (S)

block.p: The singer and pianist Steve Ross is such a master at putting a debonair spin on Cole Porter and Noel Coward's musical high jinks that his persona is that of a sophisticated party entertainer who holds off the blues with a froth of wit. But there is an introspective side to Mr. Ross that has increasingly peeked out in his recent cabaret performances.

That side is shy, dreamy and wryly self-knowing. And in his wonderful new show, ''Love and Laughter, Part 1,'' which opened an eight-week engagement at the Firebird Cafe on Wednesday, the humor is balanced by songs that have the feel of wistful sighs.

The singer and pianist Steve Ross is such a master at putting a debonair spin on Cole Porter and Noel Coward's musical high jinks that his persona is that of a sophisticated party entertainer who holds off the blues with a froth of wit. But there is an introspective side to Mr. Ross that has increasingly peeked out in his recent cabaret performances.

That side is shy, dreamy and wryly self-knowing. And in his wonderful new show, ''Love and Laughter, Part 1,'' which opened an eight-week engagement at the Firebird Cafe on Wednesday, the humor is balanced by songs that have the feel of wistful sighs.

For every two moments of delicious fun (Porter's hilarious list song of mythic sexual conquests, ''They Couldn't Compare to You,'' from ''Out of This World'' is a particular highlight) there is one of sobriety. Mr. Ross's version of ''I Can Dream, Can't I?'' finds a core of truth in a ballad that nobody else has uncovered. In his quiet, resigned interpretation, the narrator who tells an absent sweetheart, ''I'm aware my heart is a sad affair'' isn't just putting on dramatic airs. The song becomes the confession of a man who is so wounded he can love only at a distance, in fantasy.
Mr. Ross imparts a similar resonance to Porter's ''All Through the Night.''

The narrator is an obsessive fantasist who prefers his nocturnal visions to daytime reality. ''One for My Baby (and One More for the Road)'' also undergoes a striking transformation, from a loudmouthed barfly's tale of romantic woe to the monologue of someone so stunned by disappointment he can barely put words together.
This is not to say the show isn't fun. The sad songs make the laughter brighter by revealing how merriment can camouflage the diffidence of a wounded dreamer.
